answers.body_markdown:
The variable `decvalue` is not set.
You are using variables outside of double quotes then all the commands `[ $decvalue -ge ... ]` become `[ -ge ... ]`, thus the error.

You can debug your script using the -x (debug) and/or -v (verbose) option to the line `#!/bin/bash -xv`. You'll then see and understand what happens. Instead, you can also call `set -xv` to enable debug locally then `set +xv` after the lines you want to debug.

Using double quotes, the error message would be a bit more explicit:

`bash: [: : integer expression expected`

answers.body_markdown:
The source of the problem reported in the question is an empty `decvalue` as [syme][1] has already stated.

Considering the purpose of the script, it seems you attempted to write a recursive function. For this reason, i suggest you to follow the comment under your question by jww regarding debugging!

Moreover, you are encouraged to search for questions on [recursive functions in bash][2] on SO. There are excellent answers for factorial computations in bash.

Think about which quantities are "transported" and which are returned/compiled in the end. 



----------
If you are really stuck, you find 90% of the solution below.


    #!/bin/bash
    romanLetters(){
            local decvalue=$1
            local roman
            declare -i decvalue

            if [ $decvalue -ge 1000 ]; then
                    romanvalue="M$(romanLetters $((decvalue - 1000)))"
                    echo $romanvalue
            elif [ $decvalue -ge 900 ]; then
                    romanvalue="CM$(romanLetters $((decvalue - 900)))"
                    echo $romanvalue
            # ... and so on ...
            fi
    }

    echo "1900: $(romanLetters 1900)"

  [1]: https://stackoverflow.com/a/58467844/12063049
  [2]: https://stackoverflow.com/search?q=recursive%20function%20bash

Tried a few more things, and found one that worked.

Adding a character class around [:digit:] solved the problem.

    std::regex re3("(\\.[[:digit:]]+)(\\.)");

[:digit:] is apparently a class range, which must be wrapped in a character class to be parsed as an atom.

answers.body_markdown:
[`await`][1] should be used to wait for a `Promise`. But when you call `.subscribe()`, it returns a `Subscription` object. 

> If the value of the expression following the await operator is not a
> Promise, it's converted to a resolved Promise.

This means that you don't actually wait until you GET request is completed, that's why you see  'Completed' and then 'The GET observable is now completed.'


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/await

answers.body_markdown:
Unless I'm reading the question wrong, it sounds like some kind of state management solution would be useful here. That is, once you know the user's details, they should be stored in a place that is easily accessible later on from other widgets.

There are a few state management options available: 

- [`StatefulWidget`](https://flutter.dev/docs/development/ui/interactive) - a classic, simplest approach. Have a `StatefulWidget` which tracks state (user's details), and pass them down the widget tree to a component that can make use of those details. Gets a little unwieldy if you have a deep tree and need to pass the data down through several layers that don't really care about said data.
- [`InheritedWidget`](https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/widgets/InheritedWidget-class.html). Propagate information down the widget tree and rebuild UI whenever inherited widget itself changes state. Relatively straightforward, simple solution. Unlike `StatefulWidget`, you can retrieve required data where you need it, and you don't have to pass it down as arguments to yet another widget.
- [Provider package](https://pub.dev/packages/provider). A state management solution by Remi Rousselet, endorsed by Google itself. Easy to use and understand, and quite scaleable. Advertised as:
 > A mixture between dependency injection (DI) and state management, built with widgets for widgets.
- [Redux](https://pub.dev/packages/flutter_redux). Another state management solution that comes in a form of a package. If you've worked with React/Redux, you will feel right at home. It's not as full-featured as its JavaScript counterpart, but the idea is the same: have a store to which some widgets are listening, and rebuild them whenever data changes. 
- [BLoC / Rx](https://medium.com/flutterpub/architecting-your-flutter-project-bd04e144a8f1). One of the Google's recommended ways to manage state. Leans heavily on streams. Is somewhat more complex to understand, but rather powerful once you do.
- [MobX](https://github.com/mobxjs/mobx.dart). Another state management solution ported from JavaScript world. I haven't had much experience with it, but I believe it's based on observables, actions and reactions. I expect it should be quite similar to JavaScript's counterpart.

You can read more about each of those by heading over to the dedicated page on the official [documentation](https://flutter.dev/docs/development/data-and-backend/state-mgmt/options).

Personally, I'd probably choose something relatively simple first - perhaps `InheritedWidget` or `provider` package. However, it heavily depends on your use case and what programming paradigms you're comfortable with / want to experiment with.

items.body_markdown:
I have a normalized table ("IRG02_tbl") with about 74K records that contains exam scores and interpretations---I'm trying to use these to generate a report for each student. In some cases the record source I would need for this report would exceed 255 fields, so I'm trying to find a work-around.

**Data Issues**

Each student has between 32 and 64 exam scores per academic year (1 through 5), and each score has three interpretations (one for the student, one for the instructor, one for the range). Sometimes these scores are text/string (i.e., essays) but 99% of scores are numeric/double. Students repeat these assessments over time, so a "sequence" field is attached to each score/interpretation to track each administration. So: A student in year 5 may have 320 scores x 3 interpretations = 960 columns/fields. 

**Table Structure (IRG02_tbl)** 

The fields in this table are:

 - ID (autonumber/primary key)
 - StudentID (short text)
 - Sequence (double; tracks the administration, i.e., 1.0, 1.1., etc.)
 - AY (long; primary key from a lookup table for academic year 1 through 5)
 - Metric (long; primary key from a lookup table with the score name)
 - Score_Ultimate (Long Text; the student's score)
 - Interpretation_Ultimate (long; primary key from a lookup table for the interpretation for the score)
 - VarName_Revised (short text; recodes the metric name by academic year, i.e., "1_Empathy, 2_Empathy," etc.)

Here is what I've tried:

**Crosstabs**

A single crosstab query would be ideal but will not work for me here, because (1) the number of scores/interpretations is so large; (2) the Score_Ultimate field can't be used in crosstabs in Access; and (3) the three interpretations per score are each their own row. Since I can't put all the fields in one very long row, next I tried breaking the records out by academic year.

**Queries**

I used VBA to generate queries for each score, such as this one that creates a single query containing only the score (Empathy) and interpretations for the first academic year. 

    SELECT IRG02_tbl.StudentID, IRG02_tbl.AY, IRG02_tbl.Sequence, IRG02_tbl.Metric AS [P1_Empathy 
    Score_label], IRG02_tbl.Score_Ultimate AS [P1_Empathy Score_Scr], Interpretations.Short_Hand AS 
    [P1_Empathy Score_SH], Interpretations.Student_Txt AS [P1_Empathy Score_Std], 
    Interpretations.Advisor_Txt AS [P1_Empathy Score_Adv]
    FROM Interpretations INNER JOIN IRG02_tbl ON Interpretations.Interpretation_id = 
    IRG02_tbl.Interpretation_Ultimate
    WHERE (((IRG02_tbl.AY)= 1) AND ((IRG02_tbl.Metric)=6));

This generates several dozen queries depending on the academic year. For just the first year I tried to link them all together using outer joins on StudentID and Sequence---this should get me one very long row per student with less than 255 columns. The SQL statement is about 40K characters so I'm not posting it here yet when I run it, Access just freezes. 

**Making Tables**

I also tried using each of those queries to make tables, and then used SQL to join them same as above---and it still freezes. This also bloats the database and defeats the purpose of having a normalized table in the first place, but I thought it might reduce the load in running the SQL. 

**Edits to OP**
In response to comments:

 - Ultimately I'd like an Access report that shows a (single) student's scores in a chart/graph, followed by interpretations for the most current results. For example students get "empathy" scores each year; I'd want to display their previous scores and then have an interpretation for their most recent empathy score. The report would then be converted to PDF to give to the student. 
 - I've done this in the past using SPSS, exporting the data to Excel, and using a mail merge template in Word (with an Excel plug-in that does the graphs). If I can do all of this in Access that would be preferable.
 - The data source for the Report is only to generate the report; after the report is exported to PDF it is no longer needed. 
 - The main table IRG02_tbl has a primary key (ID) and StudentID is indexed with dups allowed. It has 73.6K rows.
 - The table "Interpretations" has Interpretation_id as a primary key. The field Metric_ID is indexed. The schema is that there is an Assessments table (13 rows), linked to a Metrics_LU_tbl (88 rows)-each assessment has a set of metrics that yield scores. Metrics_LU_tbl is linked to a table named Interpretations; there are about 200 rows in that table. Interpretations has two Long Text fields (Student_Txt and Advisor_Txt) contain the interpretations, and Short_Hand is a short text field that contains the range (i.e., High, Low, etc.). In a previous step a score is assigned an Interpretation_id based upon its range-that way, the Interpretation_id picks up the two interpretations and short hand interpretation. StudentID is not in this table. 
 - So if you read this far: Scoring is done outside of Access in SPSS. SPSS can handle a dataset with 1000's of columns, but SPSS can't generate interpretative (printed) reports. Results from SPSS are imported into Access and normalized, then subjected to an algorithm that compares the score and assigns the corresponding interpretation. The last step is generating a graphical/written report of the results for each individual student (not an aggregate report). 

Any help would be appreciated, cheers

answers.body_markdown:
Two ideas:

* It's generally better to listen for the DOMContentLoaded instead. The `load` event will fire only after all images, media, etc are downloaded. This may well happen *far after* the initial page load, so the browser has had time to do the initial paint in the meantime, meaning that the `load` event visibly occurs somewhat later. In contrast, DOMContentLoaded fires when the DOM is parsed and interactable, without additional delays. But, the DOM is not necessarily parsed *immediately* - there may be a bit of delay between (for example) the loading of the first half of the DOM and the loading of the rest, so in addition:

* At the start of the page, hide the main page content (say, the article) with CSS, perhaps with `article { display: none }` or something of the sort. Then, in your DOMContentLoaded listener, fiddle with the DOM / CSS and change the theme as desired, and then make the article visible. This will ensure that the initial paint that the user sees will be painted with the desired theme, rather than seeing one theme, shortly followed by the actual desired theme.

If you can make all theme changes with CSS alone, it would be even better to set the correct stylesheet *immediately*, in the `<head>`, before the body content has started to load. (Don't put the CSS part in a `DOMContentLoaded` listener.) But this is only an option if your DOM changes don't involve Javascript.

answers.body_markdown:
I'm assuming this is a homework question, but if you want a hint you can use `myString.toCharArray()` to extract a `char[]` of every character in the string and `myString.charAt(0)` to get a character at index 0 for example.

You can also construct a new String from a character array `new String(myCharArray)` thus you can trivially just

1. Take your original string and get a character array (`char[] myChars = myString.toCharArray();`, for example)
2. Copy the character array into a new, shorter one (`char[] mySubstringChars = ...`)
3. Change the shorter char array back into a String  (`String mySubstring = new String(mySubstringChars);`)

Yes, but be careful what you wish for:

    $ unset $(env | awk -F= '{print $1}') && env
    bash: env: No such file or directory

The 2nd call to **env**(1) fails because `PATH` has been deleted.  

An alternative might be `exec -c`, to execute some command from a subshell with no environment.  But a better route, if you're worried about too much stuff in the environment, is to look back and see where that excess stuff came from, and clear it up there.

Yes, what you described should work. Note that you will need to [secure your Cloud functions][1] and besides the OAuth, do not forget to configure your function-to-function authorisation layer (as I understood that you will use more Cloud Functions). I think this process can be a pain, as you will need to configure it for each function. [Here][2] you can find more details about it.

Although, what you have described should work, me, personally I would not implement that and I would go for an [Ambassador architecture][3] with a service running on 
[Cloud Run ][4],let's say, that include the security layer, also. I would not choose your architecture plan for a few reasons:

1) I think it will be more complicated to configure mainly because what I was talking before.

2) Even though it is possible and people do this, I would not use Cloud Functions for querying databases in general, because this is a process which may take some time and your Cloud Function may timeout under some specific circumstances. ( maybe if there are a lot of ongoing connections to your db in that moment, it could cause high latency ).

3) Maintenance and debugging may be a little more difficult in a ¨chain¨ system like this.

4) I think that in case of really high traffic the cloud functions based architecture may be more expensive. You can check this out using the [Pricing Calculator][5].

In conculsion, I think it will work, but I would not do it like this. 


  [1]: https://cloud.google.com/functions/docs/securing/authenticating
  [2]: https://cloud.google.com/functions/docs/securing/authenticating#function-to-function
  [3]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/architecture/patterns/ambassador

answers.body_markdown:
Your question is quite open ended but here you go.

## UI Components ##
You need your new app to look good and user friendly, these two are what i would almost always choose between they provide all the components you need to have an elegant app and are light-weight dependencies:

 1. [`react-native-paper`][1]
 2. [`react-native-elements`][2]

## State Management ##

Almost always you will need to share certain values, arrays, objects, etc. between components, to achieve this i usually decide between:

 1. [React Context][3] - if i am building a simple small scale application.
 2. [React Redux][4] - if the application needs to be highly scalable and need enable certain features Redux can help with (i.e. offline application usage, etc.)

**Note: i would highly recommend you using Redux for state management, true the boilerplate is a pain but it will help you greatly on the long run.**

## Miscellaneous ##

 1. [Expo][5] - Pretty much most of my applications use expo platform, i would say your application development timeline is cut by 1/3 using it, however the greatest downside would be the inability to integrate native modules with it like how you use `link` in a normal react native application.
 2. [Axios][6] - For any HTTP related requests
 3. [React Navigation][7] - For handling my application routing and navigation

## Bonus ##

If you are actually just starting a new application, i have just finished setting up a quick boilerplate that pretty much uses all the technologies i mentioned above. as well as pre-setup authentication flow, theming (Light and Dark theme) and some extra stuff!

Check it out on [GitHub][8] :)

Hope this Helps!

  [3]: https://reactjs.org/docs/context.html
  [4]: https://react-redux.js.org/
  [5]: https://expo.io

answers.body_markdown:
When you splice something from an array, an element gets removed, and thus the length is shortened by one.

So if you loop through an array and remove something, that means that the index for the item you are removing has now become the index for the next item. So on the next loop, that item is skipped.

To solve your problem, you need to decrement `i` when you splice something from the array, so it isn't skipped on the next iteration.

That should hopefully solve the issue!

answers.body_markdown:
You can split on the whitespace with a lookbehind to account for the period. Additionally, to account for the possibility of no whitespace, a lookahead can be used:

    import re
    some_text = "Hi there. It's a nice weather. Have a great day.It is a beautify day."
    result = re.split('(?<=\.)\s|\.(?=[A-Z])', some_text)

Output:

    ['Hi there.', "It's a nice weather.", 'Have a great day', 'It is a beautify day.']


`re` explanation:

  
`(?<=\.)` => position lookbehind, a `.` must be matched for the next sequence to be matched.

`\s` => matches whitespace (` `).

`|` => Conditional that will attempt to match either the expression to its left or its right, depending on what side matches first.

`\.` => matches a period

`(?=[A-Z])` matches the latter period if the next character is a capital letter.
answers.title: Split text but include pattern in the first splitted part

answers.body_markdown:
It would be simpler and more efficient to use `re.findall` instead of splitting in this case:

    re.findall(r'[^.]*\.', some_text)

This returns:

    ['Hi there.', " It's a nice weather.", ' Have a great day.']
answers.title: Split text but include pattern in the first splitted part

answers.body_markdown:
If each sentence always ends with a `.`, it would be simpler and more efficient to use the `str.split` method instead of using any regular expression at all:

    [s + '.' for s in some_text.split('.') if s]

This returns:

    ['Hi there.', " It's a nice weather.", ' Have a great day.']
answers.title: Split text but include pattern in the first splitted part

answers.body_markdown:
You can use capture groups with `re.split`:

    >>> re.split(r'([^.]+\.)', some_text)
    ['', 'Hi there.', '', " It's a nice weather.", '', ' Have a great day.', '']

If you want to also strip the leading spaces from the second two sentences, you can have `\s*` outside the capture group:

    >>> re.split(r'([^.]+\.)\s*', some_text)
    ['', 'Hi there.', '', "It's a nice weather.", '', 'Have a great day.', '']

Or, (with Python 3.7+ or with the [regex module][1]) use a zero width lookbehind that will split immediately after a `.`:

    >>> re.split(r'(?<=\.)', some_text)
    ['Hi there.', " It's a nice weather.", ' Have a great day.', '']

That will split the same even if there is no space after the `.`.

And you can filter the `''` fields to remove the blank results from splitting:

    >>> [field for field in re.split(r'([^.]+\.)', some_text) if field]
    ['Hi there.', " It's a nice weather.", ' Have a great day.']


  [1]: https://pypi.org/project/regex/
answers.title: Split text but include pattern in the first splitted part

`virtualenv venv` creates a virtual environment that uses Python 2. Since it isn't using Python 3, `pip3 install flask` uses the system pip3, which lives outside the virtual environment. This will install Flask outside of the virtual environment.

It's unclear how you're invoking Python. If you're typing `python3`, if you're getting the system `python3`, which will be able to import Flask.

Regardless, to correct this, remove `venv`, and build it again using

    virtualenv --python=python3 venv

and then either activate the virtual environment, or use one of the wrappers that that virtual environment provides for you. e.g.,

    venv/bin/pip install Flask

then

    FLASK_APP=app.py venv/bin/flask run

items.body_markdown:
I have a sales fact, a customer dimension, and a sales person dimension. The joins are as follows:

    Sales Fact * <----- 1 Customer Dimension (based on Customer ID)
    Customer Dimension * <----- 1 Sales Person Dimension (based on Sales Person ID)

The Sales Person ID exists on all tables. One of the features of the data is that a Sales Person can be associated with individual sales directly, within the Sales fact, or with customer's sales, by association with customers that belong to them, as recorded in the Customer Dimension.

My goal is to write DAX to capture both associations separately:

Customer-driven Sales = Sales of customers that belong to a particular Sales Person

Rep-driven Sales = Sales that were made by a Sales Person directly, even for customers that belong to a different Sales Rep

Another constraint is that I want to be able to use the Sales Person dimension attributes as the dimensions by which to present and slice all of this data in Power BI, and also as the basis of row-level security.

The customer-driven sales are easy; the default relationship between the tables handles it naturally. However, I have not been able to make the rep-driven sales measure work within ALL of my constraints. 


For instance, I have tried utilizing an inactive relationship between Sales and Sales Person directly, such as

```
CALCULATE (
    SUM[Sales],
    USERELATIONSHIP ( 'Sales Person'[Sales Person ID], 'Sales'[Sales Person ID] )
)
```

but when applying row-level security filters to the Sales Rep table, an error would occur when viewing from the perspective of the Sales Rep, because two joins would be at play at once.

I modified that first attempt slightly by placing the row-level filter on the Customer dimension instead, but that allows the Sales Person so see the other sales people that made sales for the Sales Person's customers, and that is undesired from an RLS perspective.

Then I changed the USERELATIONSHIP function to a RELATED function and returned the RLS filter to the Sales Person dimension. However, when placing the Sales Person Name field from Sales Person into a table with that measure, it only showed the sales that the Sales Person made for their own customers, ignoring the sales they made for other customers. I imagine this has to be because the relationship from Sales Person to Customer to Sales is filtering out the customers that aren't related to the Sales Person. 

That's why I'm wondering if there is a way to mimic a right outer join so that I can use the Sales Person dimension fields to group the sales facts while also aggregating some of the facts that would be filtered out by the left outer join that is occurring by virtue of that relationship.
items.title: Is it Possible to Replicate a RIGHT OUTER JOIN in DAX?

template_name = "device_app/device_list.html"

template_name = "django_tables2/bootstrap.html"

answers.body_markdown:
You need to use the try/except only on the lines of code where you expect an error. In this case, when you cast the user input to int or float.

Since you are using a for loop, you will miss a number in case of invalid input. a while loop is better in this case.

Here is something that will work:

    val = input("Enter how many numbers: ")
    
    while not val.isdigit() or val == '0':
        print("error, try again")
        val = input("Enter how many numbers: ")
    val = int(val)
    valid_nums = 0
    sums = 0
    while valid_nums < val:
        try:
            num = float(input("enter a number: "))
            valid_nums += 1
            sums += num
        except ValueError:
            print("error, try again")
            continue
    print("Average:", sums/val)

answers.title: How to convert multi header pandas dataframe to a list of nested dictionaries

answers.body_markdown:
I don't think there is a straight forward way of doing this, that being said, you could use [stack](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.stack.html) + [to_dict](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.to_dict.html) and some post-processing afterwards:

    # prepare the DataFrame
    df = df.set_index(('', 'id')).stack(level=0)
    df.index.names = ['id', None]
    
    # convert to a dicts of dicts
    d = {}
    for (idi, key), values in df.to_dict('index').items():
        d.setdefault(idi, {}).update({key: values})
    
    # convert d to list of dicts
    result = [{'id': k, **values} for k, values in d.items()]
    
**Output**

    [{'id': 1,
      'x': {'double room': 3, 'single room': 2},
      'y': {'double room': 5, 'single room': 4}},
     {'id': 3,
      'x': {'double room': 7, 'single room': 4},
      'y': {'double room': 3, 'single room': 5}}]
answers.title: How to convert multi header pandas dataframe to a list of nested dictionaries
How to convert multi header pandas dataframe to a list of nested dictionaries
How to convert multi header pandas dataframe to a list of nested dictionaries

answers.body_markdown:
I like accepted solution, but here my two alternatives wihout stacking.

This solution is straight-forward but with more columns a lot of repetition and error-prone:
```
lst = [{'id': d[('', 'id')], 
        'x': {'single room': d[('x', 'single room')], 'double room': d[('x', 'double room')]},
        'y': {'single room': d[('y', 'single room')], 'double room': d[('y', 'double room')]},}
        for d in df.to_dict('records')
]
```
Let's try make it more scalable, from https://stackoverflow.com/questions/50932755/arbitrarily-nested-dictionary-from-tuples you can get `nest` function:
```
def nest(d: dict) -> dict:
    result = {}
    for key, value in d.items():
        target = result
        for k in key[:-1]:  
            target = target.setdefault(k, {})
        target[key[-1]] = value
    return result
```
But for `('', id)` we need slighlty different behavior:
```
def nest_m(d: dict) -> dict:
    result = {}
    for key, value in d.items():
        if key == ('', 'id'):
            result['id'] = value
        else:
            target = result
            for k in key[:-1]:  
                target = target.setdefault(k, {})
            target[key[-1]] = value    
    return result
```
Final line:
```
lst = [nest_m(d) for d in df.to_dict('records')]  
```
Output:
```
[{'id': 1,
  'x': {'single room': 2, 'double room': 3},
  'y': {'single room': 4, 'double room': 5}},
 {'id': 3,
  'x': {'single room': 4, 'double room': 7},
  'y': {'single room': 5, 'double room': 3}}]
```
answers.title: How to convert multi header pandas dataframe to a list of nested dictionaries

      geom_line(aes(y=`serious accident`), colour="red", size=1.3)+
      scale_y_discrete("Accident Fatality", limits=c(0,2,4,6,8,10))+
      scale_x_discrete("year", limits=c(1985, 1990, 1995, 2000, 2005, 2010))+
      ggtitle("Major Accidents versus Serious Accidents for Under 14 CFR 121 US carriers")+
      theme_grey()+    
      legend(2010, 8, 
             c("major_accident", "`serious accident`", 
               lty=c(1,1), lwd=c(2.5,2.5), 
               col=c("dark green", "red")))
items.title: Adding a legend to the plot

items.body_markdown:
I'm seeing behavior that seems inconsistent with the documentation (LSL wiki).

- Scripts in different objects can communicate via `llRegionSay()` and `llRegionSayTo()`
- The LSL wiki for both functions recommends to _"use a very negative channel"_
- The LSL wiki for [`llRegionSayTo()`](http://wiki.secondlife.com/wiki/LlRegionSayTo) states: _"Text can be a maximum of 1024 bytes."_
- The LSL wiki for [`llRegionSay()`](http://wiki.secondlife.com/wiki/LlRegionSay) states: _"in Mono, each character occupies 2 memory bytes"_
- The LSL wiki for [`llListen()`](http://wiki.secondlife.com/wiki/LlListen) states: _"Chat on negative channels is truncated to 254 bytes"_

This would suggest a maximum string length of `127` when sending messages via `llRegionSay()` or `llRegionSayTo()` on a negative channel in a Mono script. However, I was able to successfully send a string of length `1024` between two Mono scripts on a negative channel.

I assume that (a) the wiki is outdated, (b) my interpretation is wrong or (c) the server is supporting deprecated script behavior. Can someone explain with more certainty?
items.title: How many bytes can we reliably send on a negative channel?
